awd_titl_txt: CHS: Medium: Improving the Accessibility of Mobile Applications by Enabling Third-Party Assessment, Repair, and Enhancement
awd_abstract_narration:
Many mobile applications (apps) do not properly implement accessibility services that help people with disabilities use computers, effectively denying access to apps and associated services for many vulnerable people. This project will develop new approaches to assess, repair, and enhance accessibility across large numbers of apps without needing access to source code of an app or the phone's operating system. To do this the research team will develop new pixel-level analyses of app interfaces to assess whether they correctly implement application programming interfaces (APIs) that the phone platform provides to support accessibility, then release datasets that give a picture of accessibility across the ecosystem of apps. The team will also develop new approaches that allow third parties to build alternate "proxy" interfaces that run on top of an existing app and implement accessibility APIs, as well as new approaches for those proxies to be personalized to a particular person's abilities and needs. The team will work closely with partners who serve people with disabilities in both design and evaluation of the tools, bringing direct benefits to those partners, as well as broader social benefits through actively disseminating the tools, methods, and datasets to support others in doing accessibility research. The project will also provide research and education opportunities for students from grade to grad school, with the team specifically targeting students from groups that are underrepresented in computing research, including those with disabilities.

For assessment, the team will develop methods for executing an application in a mobile phone emulator, navigating its interface using common tasks, capturing both images of the interface and its accessibility API representation, and evaluating whether a recovered pixel-based interface hierarchy from the captured image correctly corresponds to the API representation. Working with people with disabilities to develop effective summaries and presentations of the analyses, the team will develop scalable infrastructure and efficient analyses to look for patterns in types of accessibility failures, how these failures are distributed across apps and developers, and how they are affected by app updates. For repair and enhancement, the team will develop interaction proxies that leverage the platform's accessibility services to create overlay windows that cover the underlying app interface and exchange events with it. They will also develop design patterns that link common accessibility failures with repair strategies, providing libraries to quickly implement these patterns in interaction proxies to support both third-party and eventually automatic repair of these common failures. Finally, the team will explore how novel interaction techniques that respond to individual abilities could be broadly deployed via interaction proxies, using a Model-View/Controller paradigm to manage the combinatorial complexity of applying particular enhancements to particular interfaces.

por.por_cntn:
Major activities in this project included: (1) developing a framework for exploring potential insights enabled by scalable assessment of accessibility, (2) examining large-scale accessibility data through this framework, (3) developing techniques for third-party repair and enhancement of the accessibility of mobile applications, and (4) developing and examining ability-based designs, including those that can be enabled by third-party enhancements.

We developed a novel conceptual framework for examining the accessibility of mobile apps, inspired by the multi-factor ecosystem perspective of epidemiology. Although the accessibility of individual apps is important, our framework emphasizes apps do not exist in isolation. Additional benefits and insights can thus be gained by exploring accessibility at the population-level, gaining insights into the state of app accessibility and opportunities for improvements.

We first considered several accessibility issues in a population of 9,999 Android apps from the Rico dataset, analyzing accessibility of image-based elements and then expanding analysis to other common accessibility issues. We then further conducted a major new longitudinal data collection and analysis, providing the first large-scale observations of app accessibility evolution over time.

We developed novel techniques for robust annotation of mobile app interface elements, implemented for use in social annotation approaches to accessibility repairs. Although social annotation has been explored in the web, mobile apps lack a robust identifier for the context in which an annotation applies (i.e., the equivalent of a URL). We developed a new approach using screen equivalency heuristics, allowing us to define a particular screen of an app as the context for an annotation. We also later applied these techniques for low-cost unpowered tactile enhancements to existing mobile apps and a system for runtime accessibility of animated GIFs.

We also developed multiple explorations of ability-based designs: Blocks4All investigated accessible design of blocks-based programming; Crowdsensus and Crowdlicit investigated how to scale end-user elicitation of gestures, interactions, or symbols people find appropriate and intuitive; GestureCalc investigated eyes-free target-less interaction in a calculator app; Interactiles investigated fabrication of low-cost unpowered tactile enhancements to existing mobile apps; Scout investigated how high-level constraints can support automated generation of diverse alternatives for interface layout; the Ability-Based Design Mobile Toolkit examines how developers can more easily incorporate ability-based functionality in their apps.

The project directly and substantially supported PhD research activities for 12 PhD students, including 7 completed PhDs and 5 still in-progress. The research environment created by the project also indirectly supported research training for many additional students at all levels (i.e., PhD, Masters, undergraduate).

The project directly contributed to the launch of UW CREATE (https://create.uw.edu/), a new center focused on accessibility research and the translation of that research into practice, initiated with $5M of Microsoft support. All senior personnel on this project are among the founding directors of this center, which builds on the collaborations and research developed in this project.

Additional technology transfer impacts of research and training in this project have included: (1) Google improvements to Android accessibility documentation, to accessibility testing via tools like the Google Accessibility Scanner, and to Android runtime accessibility infrastructure, and (2) Apple’s launch of Screen Recognition, an accessibility enhancement that analyzes apps at runtime to repair missing accessibility metadata for common interface elements. Research conducted in this award has thus informed accessibility advances in both major mobile platforms.

Large-scaled mobile accessibility analyses conducted in this project have also been highlighted in U.S. Department of Justice proposals to revise both the regulations implementing Title II of the Americans with Disabilities Act (i.e., the primary federal policy which drives technology accessibility requirements in government services) and the regulations implementing Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 (i.e., the primary federal policy which drives technology accessibility requirements for organizations that receive federal funding).
